align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 19.0pt; text-align: center; mso-line-height-alt: 0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Bangladesh Legal Practitioner and </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Bar Council Order, 1972</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 19.0pt; text-align: center; mso-line-height-alt: 0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">(P.O. 46 of 1972)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 19.0pt; text-align: center; mso-line-height-alt: 0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Article 8</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 10.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 109%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Article 8 is not mandatory rather it is directory-Where a stature requires some-thing to be done in a particular manner and the consequence of failure to do so are also provided no difficulty arise and the provision is construed as mandato-ry but when the stature does not specify the con-sequences of failure to do something in a partic-</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 109%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">ular manner such provision is directory.</span> <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 109%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">The Secretary Bangladesh Bar Council Vs. A. F. M. Faiz &amp; others, (Civil), 2LNJ 42</span></em></p><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View>  <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom>  <w:TrackMoves/>  <w:TrackFormatting/> Name="Light Grid Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="19" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="21" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="31" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="32" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="33" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Book Title"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:10.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: center; mso-line-height-alt: 0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Articles 34(8) </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">and 36(1)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 107%;"><span style="font-size: 10.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 107%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Admittedly, the instant appeal before this Division was preferred by the complainant-appellant being aggrieved by the impugned judgment and order of the High Court Division in respect of modification of the order of sen-tence debarring the respondent No.1 from prac-ticing in the legal profession permanently for life to a period of 5(five) years on the ground that it was not in conformity with the gravity of the offence committed by the respondent No.1. The Respondent No. 1 committed gross Professional misconduct of the highest decree which not only obstructed the administration of justice but also eroded the reputation of the Legal Profession in the opinion of the public and that not being enrolled as an advocate and engaged on behalf of the appellant, the respon-dent No. 1 represented himself as an engaged Advocate on behalf of the appellant in objection case before the Assistant Settlement Officer and that the respondent No. 1 being an Advocate of the other side expressed his desire by his letters dated 17-05-1998 and 07-06-1998 to help the complainant-appellant in a wakf case out of the way and thus the respondent no.1 intended to represent conflicting interests and thereby com-mitted gross professional misconduct and as such the sentence of debarring the respondent No. 1 from pursuing legal profession permanent-ly for life is not at all harsh, rather, it is very much conformity with the offence committed by him. The respondent No. 1 behavior was very much unbecoming as a member of the noble pro-fession and the Bangladesh Bar Council rightly took disciphrary proceedings against him. <em>Esrarul Huq Chowdhury Vs. Md. Amir Hossain Advocate and another (Civil) 2 LNJ 169</em><br/></span></p></div></div>
2589	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Legal Practitioners and Bar Council Order (PO 98 of 1972)</h2>

Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Bangladesh Legal Practitioners and Bar Council Order (PO 98 of 1972)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Article 8</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The word 'shall' as used in Article 8 has to be considered as merely directory. The neglect of which does not affect the validity or involve any other consequence if the election is held within the shortest possible time after 31st May in order to run the affairs of the Bar Council by the elected body following democratic process. In such view of the matter, the High Court Division was pleased to direct the Bar Council to correct the voter list, if any error is detected within 10 days from today and communicate the same to the respective polling station. The Chairman, Bar Council was directed to refix the date of holding election and the date of objection thereof. The Chairman, Bar Council was further directed to take effective steps so that one voter cannot cast his vote twice. <span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Muhammad Salahuddin and others Vs. The Bar Council and others, (Special), 2 LNJ 130</em></span></p></div></div>
2590	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh legal Practitioners and Bar Council Rules, 1972</h2>

table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:8.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:107%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Bangladesh legal Practitioners and Bar Council Rules, 1972</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Rule 65A (ii)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The impugned proviso to rule 65 A (ii) of Bangladesh Legal Practitioners and Bar Council Rules, 1972 imposing restriction on the practice of all the ex-Judicial Officers in the subordinate Court of Bangladesh is arbitrary, unreasonable, irrational and illogical which is struck down as being without lawful authority and is of no legal effect. After being enrolled as Advocates, all exJudicial Officers, as we see it, stand on the same footing with other Advocates. All Advocates, whether they are ex-Judicial Officers or not, form a class by themselves. Since they are a class by themselves, there can not be any discrimination amongst themselves in the absence of any 'intelligible differentia' or 'permissible criteria'. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">A.K.M. Fazlul Karim<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Vs.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>The Government of Bangladesh, (Spl. Original) 1 LNJ 97</em></span></p></div></div>
2591	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Merchant Shipping Ordinance, (XXVI of 1983)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  5(2) LNJ 351, </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1983</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Service Rules</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-04-02</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:8.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:107%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Bangladesh Merchant Shipping Ordinance, (XXVI of 1983)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 2(45)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The employment of any Bangladeshi Seaman in any ship or vessel, either Bangladeshi or foreign, is regulated by the provision of Bangladesh Merchant Shipping Ordinance 1983. The persons employed as such are known as 'Sea man' which has been defined in section 2(45) of the said ordinance which excluded the 'Master' of the vessel. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Captain Md. Abdul Hayee Miah and others Vs. ,M.V. Ocean Pearl and others, (Admiralty), 5(2) LNJ<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>351</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Sections 8 and 131</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">From the provisions of section 131 of the Ordinance it appears that every Bangladesh seaman is liable to hold a 'continuous discharge certificate' (CDC) book issued by the Government shipping master in the prescribed format, wherein their engagement in any employment in any vessel and his discharge from such vessel must be endorsed by the Master of the vessel. The authority known as 'Shipping Master' is engaged by the government under the provision of section 8 of the Bangladesh Merchant Shipping Ordinance, 1983. Captain Md. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Abdul Hayee Miah and others Vs. M.V. Ocean Pearl and others, (Admiralty), 5(2) LNJ <span style="mso-spacerun: yes;"> </span>351</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Sections 89 and 106</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">It appears from section 89 of the Bangladesh Merchant Shipping Ordinance 1983 that in lieu of CDC book any similar document may be issued by the Shipping Master to the seaman and further the 'provision of section 106 of the said acts provides for holding by every seaman's identity card issued by the government with prescribed particulars to be noted in it. These documents shall prove the lawful employment and discharge of seaman in a marine vessel and through which a liability will be imposed upon the owner of the vessel to pay the wages. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Captain Md. Abdul Hayee Miah and others Vs. M.V. Ocean Pearl and others, (Admiralty), 5(2) LNJ 351</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 107</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The simple meaning of the aforesaid provision is that no person shall be employed or engaged on board a ship, unless the seamen be issued with a 'Continuous discharge certificate' (CDC) book or other similar document by the Government Shipping Master for recording details of his service. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Captain Md. Abdul Hayee Miah and others Vs. M.V. Ocean Pearl and others, (Admiralty), 5(2) LNJ 351</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 131</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The provision of section 131 of the Merchant Shipping Ordinance, 1983 deals with the issue of entries to be made in 'continuous discharge certificate' when the seaman is discharged from the job. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Captain Md. Abdul Hayee Miah and others Vs. M.V. Ocean Pearl and others, (Admiralty), 5(2) LNJ 351</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 131</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The provision section 131 mandates that the discharge of the seaman from the service has to be endorsed in the Continuous Discharge Certificate book by the 'Master of the vessel' in order to make the discharge from the job a lawful one. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Captain Md. Abdul Hayee Miah and others Vs. M.V. Ocean Pearl and others, (Admiralty), 5(2) LNJ 351</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Sections 131</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">This e-mail correspondences, exhibit 18 (series) along with the exhibit No. 24(1) and 24(7), may be taken into consideration as reflecting more or less true position of the dues remains unpaid to the plaintiff's. Therefore it may be believed partly that the plaintiff's, mentioned therein, are lawfully entitled to their salary and wages upto the amount and date as mentioned therein. Practically this is the actual amount of due salary of the plaintiffs till the plaintiffs have filed the suit on 9.5.2012.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>The plaintiffs, if at all entitled to their unpaid due wages and salary, they are entitled to get the same up to the date shown therein in exhibit No. 24(1) 24(7) and 18 (series), when some of them have signed off. The plaintiffs are jointly entitled to a decree for an amount of Tk. 2,04,44,510.35 (two crore four lac forty four thousand five hundred ten and thirty five paisa only) equivalent to US$ 1 @ of 82 per US dollar as their due salary and wages. The plaintiffs are not entitled to any other relief in the instant suit. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Captain Md. Abdul Hayee Miah and others Vs. M.V. Ocean Pearl and others, (Admiralty), 5(2) LNJ 351</em></span></p></div></div>
2592	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Passport Order (PO 9 of 1973)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  3 LNJ 1</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1973</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Fundamental Right</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-04-02</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:8.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:107%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Bangladesh Passport Order (PO 9 of 1973)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Articles 6 and 7</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Withholding/refusal of Machine Readable Passport (for shortly MRP) of the petitioner seeking surrendering of his handwritten passport on the ground of pendency of a criminal case or that a charge sheet is submitted against him runs contrary to law. A citizen's right to passport is a fundamental right, linked with freedom of movement for which personal liberty cannot be denied or curtailed. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Abdul Matin Sarker Vs. Bangladesh and others, (Spl. Original), 3 LNJ 1</em></span></p></div></div>
2593	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Public Service Commission (Consultation) Regulation, 1979 </h2>

Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:10.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 107%; margin: 0in 13.0pt .0001pt 20.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 107%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Bangladesh Public Service Commission (Consultation) Regulation, 1979 </span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 107%; margin: 0in 13.0pt .0001pt 20.0pt;"> </p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 107%; margin: 0in 13.0pt .0001pt 20.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 107%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Regulation 6</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 9.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 120%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Considering regulation 6, it appears that before passing any order of imposing penalty of removal, dismissal, compulsory retirement from service, or reduction in rank of a Class-I and Class-II Gazetted Officer consultation with Public Service Commission is mandatory. On consideration of section 3 of the Ordinance vis-a-vis regulation 6 of the Regulations of 1979 it is obvious that con-sultation with Public Service Commission is mandatory before passing the order of dismissal in respect of each of the respondent as section 3 of the Ordinance has not ousted the operation of other laws, rules and regulations. <em>Bangladesh and others Vs. Md. Bellal Hossain Mollik and another (Civil), 5 (1) LNJ 164</em></span></p></div></div>
2594	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha Employees Service Regulations, 1995 </h2>

Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:10.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 108%; margin: 0in 7.0pt .0001pt 20.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 108%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha Employees Service Regulations, 1995 </span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 108%; margin: 0in 7.0pt .0001pt 20.0pt;"> </p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 108%; margin: 0in 7.0pt .0001pt 20.0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 108%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Regulation 54(2)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 108%; margin: 0in 7.0pt .0001pt 20.0pt;"> </p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: times\ new\ roman, times, serif;"><span style="font-size: 9.5pt; line-height: 119%;">The power exercised under Regulation 55(2) of the Chittagong Port Authority Employees' Service Regulations, 1991 and Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha Employees Service Regulations, 1995 was illegal as there was no guideline formulated for exercise of such power. Consequently, the order of termination made under those provisions of law cannot be sustained in law. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 104%;">Abdul Baque and another Vs. Bangladesh and others, (Civil), 5(1)LNJ 178</span></em>  </span></p></div></div>
2595	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Service Rules</h2>

5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:8.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:107%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Bangladesh Service Rules</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Rule 9</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">In order to prevent manifest injustice from being perpetuated the entry of date of birth in the service book may be corrected, provided such correction stands the test of reasonableness. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Pragati Industries Ltd. of Barabkunda, Vs. A. K. M. Mafizur Rahman alias Mafizur Rahman and others, (Special Original), 2 LNJ 540</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Bangladesh Service Rules, Part-I.</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Rule 72(a)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">An acquittal of charges given by a criminal court on benefit of doubt or, in other words, upon failure of the prosecution to prove its case beyond reasonable doubt amounts to 'honourable acquittal' as contemplated in Rule 72(a). <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Mst. Razia Akhter Vs. Bangladesh and others, (Spl. Original), 3 LNJ 170</em></span></p></div></div>

Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:10.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 19.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 108%;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 108%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha Order, 1972, (PO No. 128 of 1972)</span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 108%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;"> </span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 19.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 108%;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 108%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Articles 32 and 33</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 120%;"><span style="font-size: 9.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 120%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">As per Article 32 clause (b) of the Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha Order, 1972 the violation of the terms and conditions of the loan agreement by the respondents has made the appellant entitled to have the repayment of the loan in full. Article 33 clause (1) (d) of the Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha Order, 1972 contemplates payment of "any other sum" relating to loan with the original loan money when the Sangstha becomes entitled to payment of any loan by reason of the breach of any condition of any agreement between the Sangstha and an industrial concern to which any loan has been granted. Here the expression "any other sum" definitely connotes a sum adjudged as compensa-tion for the breach of contract and to determine the extent of compensation existing bank rate of inter-est can be taken into consideration. </span><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 120%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">BSRS Vs. She Shipping Lines Ltd. and others, (Civil), 4LNJ 18</span></em></p></div></div>
2597	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Srama Ain (XLII of 2006)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  3 LNJ 207</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2006</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Service Rules</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-04-02</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View>  <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom>  <w:TrackMoves/>  <w:TrackFormatting/>  <w:PunctuationKerning/>  <w:ValidateAgainstSchemas/> <w:LidThemeOther>EN-US</w:LidThemeOther>  <w:LidThemeAsian>X-NONE</w:LidThemeAsian>  <w:LidThemeComplexScript>X-NONE</w:LidThemeComplexScript>  <w:Compatibility>   <w:BreakWrappedTables/> table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:8.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:107%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times 'Times New Roman','serif';">Bangladesh Srama Ain (XLII of 2006)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Sections 2(65), 2(49) and 233 (S)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The Labour Court as well as Labour Appellate Tribunal allowed the case of the respondent Nos. 3 to 21 finding them as workers of the Company as defined in Section 233 (S) of the </span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Bangladesh Srama Ain</span> 2006. Mere designation does not deter-mine whether an employee is an Officer or a Worker which is clearly embodied in section 233(S) of </span><span style="font-family: SutonnyMJ; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';">evsjv‡`k kªg AvBb</span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"> 2006. The respondent No. 22-company like the petitioner failed to show that the respondent Nos.3 to 21 ever performed the managerial or administr-ative functions of the company other than workers. The respondent Nos. 3 to 21 are the workers of the respondent No. 22- company and they are entitled to get benefit from the (Worker Participation) Profit Fund. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Unilever Bangladesh Vs. Chairman Labour Appellate Tribunal, (Spl. Original), 3 LNJ 207</em></span></p></div></div>
2598	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bangladesh Telecommunication Act (XVIII of 2001)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  2LNJ 186</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  2001</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Telecommunication </p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-03-10</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View>  <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom>  <w:TrackMoves/>  <w:TrackFormatting/>  <w:PunctuationKerning/> style="font-size: 10.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 116%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;"> Section 3(2) and 55</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 118%;"><span style="font-size: 9.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 118%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">The appellant-company admittedly has neither exhausted the forum for disposal of the application dated 08.10.2009 by the MOI nor obtained requi-site licences and NOC from the MOPT and the MOI respectively for broadcasting television before obtaining frequency and licence for estab-lishing, operating or using radio apparatus for the purpose of radio communication from the BTRC under Section 55 of the B.T. Act, 2001. For the aforesaid reasons, there is no illegality in the impugned orders passed by the respondents as con-tained in Annexures-A and A1 to stop the test trans-mission of their TV Channel and the seizure of the appellants' machineries and equipments installed in the television station under the seizure list. </span><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 9.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 135%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Jamuna Television Ltd. and another Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others, (Civil), 2LNJ 186</span></em></p></div></div>
2599	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bank Companies Act (XVII of 1991)</h2>

3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false" Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 6"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="19" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="21" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Emphasis"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="31" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Subtle Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="32" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Intense Reference"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="33" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" QFormat="true" Name="Book Title"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="37" Name="Bibliography"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:8.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:107%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Bank Companies Act (XVII of 1991)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Sections 27Ka and 27Ka Ka</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">So for<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>as the provisions<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>under section 2CC are concerned, there is no<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>ambiguity<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>that<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>the SEC is empowered to impose<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>conditions<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>on the issuer company<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>time<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>to<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>time. Under the impugned notifications, a sponsordirector will losc his post as the same will fall vacant if he fails to hold 2% share-holding, This will strip him off all his power in the management of the company as sponsor-director. The impugned notifications and subsequent clarification thereto have been legally issued by the SEC under section 2CC of the SEO-I969. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Sk. Abdul Momin Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others, (Special Original), 2 LNJ 480</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 27(1)(a)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 27(1)(a) of the Bank Companies Act, 1991, requires permission of a lender bank in the case of transfer of shares to be made voluntarily by the share holder of a borrower company and in the case of voluntary resignation tendered by the directors of a borrower company pursuant to their own decision. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Mr. Nuher Latif Khan and others Vs. Desh Energy Ltd. and others, (Original Civil), 4 LNJ 8</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 27(a)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The bar provided in section 27(a) of the Bank Companies Act is not applicable in the matter of transferring of the shares pursuant to court's order passed under section 233 of the Act or in the matter of a consequent resignation or vacation of office pursuant to order passed under section 233. Besides, when entire shares of the petitioners are transferred to the respondents then the petitioners have no stake in the company and there is no reason to saddle them with liability of the company in running and managing which they have no say, nor do they have any right to claim any interest in the profit. So, they will have no personal liability for the loan of a company after their relation with the company has been perpet-ually served. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Mr. Nuher Latif Khan and others Vs. Desh Energy Ltd. and others, (Original Civil), 4 LNJ 8</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 5(GaGa)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">It is clear that the assertions and averments made by the petitioners in different petitions that the amount received from the negotiating bank is a "sale proceed" does not at all merit substance. We hold that it is absolutely an "advance" taken by the customer within the meaning of section 2 of the Artha Rin Ain, 2003 that defines advance as a loan and therefore, attracts section 5 (GAGA) of the Bank Company Act and for that reason inclusion of the names of the petitioners in the list of CIB is justified. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Alvi Spinning Mills Ltd. and others Vs.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Bangladesh and others, (Spl. Original), 4 LNJ 568</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 45</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 45 of the Act gives a clear indication, as to which situation Bangladesh Bank shall act and the petitioners failed to show us any legal right under section 45 of the Act which imposed a legal duty upon the Bangladesh Bank. Therefore, the petitioners are not entitled to seek any relief under section 45 of the Banking Companies Act, 1991 and as such these writ petitions are not maintainable in law. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Alvi Spinning Mills Ltd. and others Vs.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Bangladesh and others, (Spl. Original), 4 LNJ 568</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Sections 5 GaGa and 27 KaKa</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The exercise of any statutory power by the public functionaries must be just, fair, reasonable, transparent, bonafide, and their actions must be consistent ,and, as such, the impugned CIB list maintained by the office of the respondent Nos. 1-3, showing the petitioners as a loan defaulter while simultaneously rescheduling the loan is a self contradictory act on the part of the respondents and is in clear violation of the relevant provisions of law, in particular the provisions of sub-section 3 of Section<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>27 KaKa of the Bank Companies Act, 1991. Therefore, inclusion of the petitioner's names in the CIB list is unlawful being in contravention of the statutory provisions provided for in the Bank Companies Act, 1991 and is in utter disregard of the fundamental rights of the petitioner guaranteed under the constitution. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Shoel Textile and others Vs. Bangladesh Bank and others, (Spl. Original), 5(1) LNJ 259</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Sections 5 GaGa and 27 KaKa</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The process of enlistment of any defaulter name in the CIB<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>list<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>is<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>a<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>continuing process<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>within the<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>meaning<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>of<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>section 5 GaGa read with section 27 KaKa of Banking Companies<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Act,<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>1991 and<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>also<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>read<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>with<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Article 42 of Bangladesh Bank Order, 1972. If all these provisions are read together one and only inference that could be made is that if any person or a company is indebted to in any manner with any financial institution and the debt remains unpaid, it is the duty of the respondent Bangladesh Bank in its turn to enlist the name of the incumbent in the CIB list nothing more nothing less. The petitioner herein is indeed a defaulter borrower within section 5 GaGa read with section 27 KaKa of the Bank Company Act and Article 42 of Bangladesh Bank Order 1972. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Shafi A Choudhury Vs. Bangladesh and others, (Spl. Original), 5(1) LNJ 295</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 7</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">A depositor, when deposits his money in the bank, is entitled to expect that his banker, under any circumstances, will not dishonour his cheque when he has sufficient fund in the account or will not stop him from withdrawing money from his account or transferring the same to another account, unless the banker is directed by a competent court, or in some cases by the regulatory authority like Bangladesh Bank, to stop such payment or transaction. Even if some bills or LCs are the subject matter of any investigation by any agency, we do not find any provision in the relevant laws under which a bank can stop payment or re-imbursement on such LCs. A bank under the law and banking practice, in particular in accordance with the relevant provisions of UCP-600, is bound to make payment or re-imbursement in respect of the accepted bills once they are accepted by the issuing banks, and in view of the said provisions of the UCP-600, namely Article-16, once such acceptance is given, the matter is closed and the concerned banks are precluded from raising any issue thereafter. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Delta Spinners Limited Vs.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>Bangladesh Bank and others, (Spl. Original), 5(1) LNJ 277</em></span></p></div></div>
2600	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bankruptcy Act (X of 1997)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  5(2)LNJ 91</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1997</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Bankruptcy Case</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-03-10</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View>  <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom>  <w:TrackMoves/>  <w:TrackFormatting/>  <w:PunctuationKerning/> Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 41pt; text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Bankruptcy Act (X of 1997)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 48pt; text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Sections 5(1), 28 and 110</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19pt; line-height: 111%; text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 111%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">A reading of section 110 shows that it has empowered the Adalat to exercise inherent<a name="page10"></a> </span><span style="font-size: 10.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 111%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">power when an application is made by a debtor or creditor of receiver for securing ends of jus-tice or to prevent the abuse of the process of the Adalat subject to the condition that the Adalat shall not exercise the power of inherent jurisdic-tion if there is a specific provision for remedy in the Act. So there being specific provision in sec-tion 28 of the Ain and in bidhi 11 of the Bidhimala for rejection of the plaint, the Adalat could not reject the plaint invoking its power under sections 5(1) and 110 of the Ain. </span><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 102%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Shinepukur Holdings Ltd. Vs. Abdur Rashid Chowdhury and others, (Civil), 5(2)LNJ 91</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 1.65pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly;"> </p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 19pt; line-height: 107%; text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Sections 5(1), 28, 96 and 110</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 0.5pt; text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 10.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 107%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">From a reading of sections 5 and 110 of the Ain, we find no difficulty to come to the conclusion that the plaint could not be rejected under the said sections and, in fact, the plaint was rejected under section 28 of the Ain. But the Adalat wrongly invoked sections 5(1) and 110 of the Ain in rejecting the plaint. Mere mentioning of wrong sections of the Ain or invoking of the wrong sections of the Ain shall not, in any way, change the colour and complexion of the order and in determining the nature of the order, its contents have to be looked into. Since the Adalat rejected the plaint and section 28 of the Ain is the only section under which it could reject the plaint, it must be presumed that the plaint was rejected under section 28 of the Ain. Therefore, the order of rejection of the plaint was appeal-able under section 96(5) of the Ain. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 104%; font-family: 'Times New Roman', 'serif';">Shinepukur Holdings Ltd. Vs. Abdur Rashid Chowdhury and others, (Civil), 5(2)LNJ 91</span></em></p><p> </p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 19.0pt; text-align: center; mso-line-height-alt: 0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Section 28</span></strong></p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 115%;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 105%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">A reading of section 28 of the Ain and bidhi 11 of the Bidhimala clearly show that the Adalat can reject a plaint of a ‡`Dwjqv suit if the condi-tions mentioned therein are present. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Times New Roman', 'serif';">Shinepukur Holdings Ltd. Vs. Abdur Rashid Chowdhury and others, (Civil), 5(2)LNJ 91</span></em></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: center; mso-line-height-alt: 0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Sections 96(5)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 120%;"><span style="font-size: 9.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 120%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">As the order passed under section 28 of the Ain is appealable under section 96(5) thereof, that was an equally efficacious remedy. It may also be stat-ed that besides filing the appeal under section 96(5) of the Ain, the plaintiff had other remedies under bidhi 26(3) of the Bidhimala, i.e. he could file a fresh suit within 30 days from the date of the order or could file an application for setting aside the order rejecting the plaint. So, the plain-tiff in any view of the matter could not invoke the jurisdiction of judicial review of the High Court Division under article 102 of the Constitution, the writ petition was not maintainable.</span><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 104%; font-family: 'Times New Roman', 'serif';">Shinepukur Holdings Ltd. Vs. Abdur Rashid Chowdhury and others, (Civil), 5(2)LNJ 91</span></em></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 11.25pt; mso-line-height-rule: exactly;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;"> </span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: center; mso-line-height-alt: 0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Rule 11</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 104%;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 104%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">A reading of section 28 of the Ain and bidhi 11 of the Bidhimala clearly show that the Adalat can reject a plaint of a </span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 104%; font-family: 'Arial','sans-serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: Arial;">‡`Dwjqv</span><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 104%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;"> suit if the condi-tions mentioned therein are present.</span><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 104%; font-family: 'Times New Roman', 'serif';">Shinepukur Holdings Ltd. Vs. Abdur Rashid Chowdhury and others, (Civil), 5(2)LNJ 91</span></em></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: center; mso-line-height-alt: 0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Rule 11</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 107%;"><span style="font-size: 10.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 107%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">A reading of section 110 shows that it has empowered the Adalat to exercise inherent power when an application is made by a debtor or creditor of receiver for securing ends of jus-tice or to prevent the abuse of the process of the Adalat subject to the condition that the Adalat shall not exercise the power of inherent jurisdic-tion if there is a specific provision for remedy in the Act. So there being specific provision in sec-tion 28 of the Ain and in bidhi 11 of the Bidhimala for rejection of the plaint, the Adalat could not reject the plaint invoking its power under sections 5(1) and 110 of the Ain.</span><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 104%; font-family: 'Times New Roman', 'serif';">Shinepukur Holdings Ltd. Vs. Abdur Rashid Chowdhury and others, (Civil), 5(2)LNJ 91</span></em></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 19.0pt; text-align: center; mso-line-height-alt: 0pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Rule 26(3)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 19pt; text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 10.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 107%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">As the order passed under section 28 of the Ain is appealable under section 96(5) thereof, that was an equally efficacious remedy. It may also be stated that besides filing the appeal under section 96(5) of the Ain, the plaintiff had other remedies under bidhi 26(3) of the Bidhimala, i.e. he could file a fresh suit within 30 days from the date of the order or could file an appli-cation for setting aside the order rejecting the plaint. So, the plaintiff in any view of the mat-ter could not invoke the jurisdiction of judicial review of the High Court Division under article 102 of the Constitution, the writ petition was not maintainable. </span><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 104%; font-family: 'Times New Roman', 'serif';">Shinepukur Holdings Ltd. Vs. Abdur Rashid Chowdhury and others, (Civil), 5(2)LNJ 91</span></em></p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19pt; line-height: 111%; text-align: justify;"> </p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19pt; line-height: 111%; text-align: justify;"> </p></div></div>
2601	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Bengal Tenancy Act (VIII of 1885)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1 LNJ 89, 5(2) LNJ 57, </p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1885</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Immoveable Property</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-04-02</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:8.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:107%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Bengal Tenancy Act (VIII of 1885)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 2 (6), 2 (13) and (17)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">The PW1 in his cross-examination has admitted the C.S. Khatian to be correctly prepared adding "bvwjkx wm. Gm. LwZqvb mwVK". If that admission is read together with section 2(6), 2(13) and 2(17) of the Bengal Tenancy Act, 1885 the same bears a presumption that the C.S. recorded tenant Khairat Ali Jobed Ali and Kachu Bewa were tenant out and out having occupancy right and Josoda Sundari and Gurupada were landlord having rent-receiving interest. So Khairat Ali and others were although recorded as "Korfa" tenant but since they paid rent at a fixed rate along with "cess" they must be held to be raiyati tenant with occupancy right in the suit holding and Joshoda and others were Jaminder having rent receiving interest. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Md. Foyez Sarkar and another Vs. Md. Rois Uddin died his heirs. (Civil) 1 LNJ 89</em></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 2 (17)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">In the instant case without acting as per law the defendant No. 24 by submitting cross written statement, supported the entire plaintiff's case and the appellate Court without taking any evidence allowed his prayer and granted a saham for 20 decimals. Since the plaintiffs and the defendant No. 24 stands on the same footing, there is no community interest of the defendant No. 24 or 25 in the suit holding and they are not co-sharers within the meaning of Section 2(17) of Bengal Tenancy Act. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Md. Foyez Sarkar and another Vs. Md. Rois Uddin died his heirs, (Civil) 1 LNJ 89</em>.</span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 103 B(5)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">It is apparent from the said finding, made by the trial Court that the defendant respondents without challenging the record of right of Momiruddin Munshi, the predecessor of the plaintiff, could not Mutate their name in accordance with law. This assertion of the trial Court goes in favour of the plaintiff-appellant at this stage whereas he dismissed the suit with-<span style="mso-tab-count: 1;">    </span>out stating reason therein and thereby not sustainable by this Court. If so required they (defendants) ought to have corrected the record of right. In the light of this proposition of law, it was held in the case of Abdul Hafez and another Vs. Lal Meah &amp; others reported in 38 D.L.R. (1986) 327 and Akrab Ali and others Vs. Zahiruddin Kari and others reported in 30 D.L.R. (SC) (1978) 81 that according to section 103 B(5) of the Bengal Tenancy Act every entry in the record of right finally published shall be evidence of the matter referred to in such entry and shall be presumed to be correct until it is proved to be incorrect. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">Md. Abul Hossain Vs. Farid Ahmed and others, (Civil), 5(2) LNJ 57</em></span></p></div></div>
2602	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Building Construction Act, 1952 (II of 1953)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  2 LNJ 513</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1952</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Construction</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-04-02</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>  <o:RelyOnVML/>  <o:AllowPNG/> </o:OfficeDocumentSettings></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="39" QFormat="true" Name="TOC Heading"/> </w:LatentStyles></xml><![endif]--><!-- [if gte mso 10]><style> /* Style Definitions */ table.MsoNormalTable	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin-top:0in;	mso-para-margin-right:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:8.0pt;	mso-para-margin-left:0in;	line-height:107%;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;	mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;	mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";	mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;}</style><![endif]--></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Building Construction Act, 1952 (II of 1953)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">Section 3(B)(5)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">BGMEA has not acquired any title because there has been no transfer of title through a device recognised by any provision of the Transfer of Property (TP) Act, 1882 and the Registration Act, 1908. The purported allotment intimated through a couple of memo issued by the Ministry and EPB, was tant-amount to a totally vacuous moves. It was neither a sale nor even a lease. Neither the BGMEA's pleading nor those of any other party, depict any instrument of title in BGMEA's favour. Although the building in dispute was erected well after C.S. survey, again, there is nothing whatsoever to show BGMEA's title or even possession vide any post C.S. survey. These reflect perpetuation by BGMEA of a series of pernicious acts of inexonerable proportion, amounting to fraud and deceit. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">They have, raised a building on the government land, effectively frustrating the long cherished Hatirjheel Project. The very presence of the building shows that a conglomerate of financially affluent people can scorn and unravel our law with impunity in a nauseating manner. Such a view is simply repulsive to notion of justice. We cannot allow a class of privileged people to flout the law because they are rich.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';">There is nothing in section 3(B)(5) of the Act to say that receipt of fine amounts to legalizing unapproved construction. What section 3(B)(5) says is that no dismantling order shall be made unless it is found that (a) such building .. . . has been constructed . . . in a manner which is contrary to the Master Plan or development plan .<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span>. . . . (d) sanction if prayed for could not be granted. The Rule is hence made absolute, as it is so destined, coupled with the direction that the authorities will demolish the building within 90 days. <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">The State Vs. Government of Bangladesh and others, (Special Original), </em></span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif';"><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">2 LNJ 513</em></span></p></div></div>
2603	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Building Construction Act, (II of 1953)</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  5(2) LNJ 107</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1953</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Building Construction</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-03-10</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View>  <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom>  <w:TrackMoves/>  <w:TrackFormatting/>  <w:PunctuationKerning/> style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Building Construction Act, </span></strong><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">(II of 1953)</span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 19pt; text-align: center;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Section 3B(5)(d)</span></strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-size: 10.5pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 107%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Considering all these aspects we do not find any reason to interfere with the impugned judgment and order of the High Court Division which is well reasoned and based on proper appreciation of facts and circumstances as well as the law. As such we have no hesitation to hold that the BGMEA building complex has been constructed by the petitioner illegally in violation of all the laws of the land which cannot stay upright rather the same deserves to be demolished at once. Thus the contention of Mr. Rafiqul Huq that the defect in title or in constructing the said building can be cured under section 43 of the Transfer of Property Act, or section 3B(5)(d) of the Building Construction Act 1952 or under any other law, is not at all sustainable. </span><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 107%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">President, BGMEA Vs. Bangladesh and others, (Civil) 5(2) LNJ 107</span></em><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 107%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; 2604	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Chittagong Port Authority Employees' Service Regulations, 1991 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  5(1)LNJ 178</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1991</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Service Rules</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-03-10</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View>  <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom>  <w:TrackMoves/>  <w:TrackFormatting/>  <w:PunctuationKerning/> Normal";	mso-tstyle-rowband-size:0;	mso-tstyle-colband-size:0;	mso-style-noshow:yes;	mso-style-priority:99;	mso-style-qformat:yes;	mso-style-parent:"";	mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;	mso-para-margin:0in;	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;	font-size:11.0pt;	font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif";	mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;	mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 108%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Chittagong Port Authority Employees' Service Regulations, 1991 </span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 108%; margin: 0in 16.0pt .0001pt -.95pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 108%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;"> </span></strong></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 108%; margin: 0in 16.0pt .0001pt -.95pt;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 108%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Regulation 55(2)</span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-right: 19.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 102%;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 102%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">The power exercised under Regulation 55(2) of the Chittagong Port Authority Employees' Service Regulations, 1991 and Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha Employees Service Regulations, 1995 was illegal as there was no guideline formulated for exercise of such power. Consequently, the order of termination made under those provisions of law cannot be sus-tained in law. </span><em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 104%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: Arial;">Abdul Baque and another Vs. Bangladesh and others, (Civil), 5(1)LNJ 178</span></em></p><p> </p></div></div>
2605	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908) </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p><b>Citation:</b>  1LNJ 3, 1LNJ 41, 1LNJ 100, 1 LNJ 124, 2LNJ 121, 2LNJ 129, 2 LNJ 33, 2LNJ 1, 3 LNJ 27, 3 LNJ 1, 3 LNJ 167, 3 LNJ 43, 3 LNJ 106, 4 LNJ 114, 4 LNJ 179, 4 LNJ 197, 4LNJ 292, 5(1)LNJ 16, 5(1)LNJ 22, 5(1)LNJ 125, 5(1)LNJ 56, 5(1)LNJ 59, 5 (1) LNJ 14, 5 (2) LNJ</p><p><b>Case Year:</b>  1908</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Civil Law</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2018-03-11</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso 9]><xml> <w:WordDocument>  <w:View>Normal</w:View>  <w:Zoom>0</w:Zoom>  <w:TrackMoves/>  <w:TrackFormatting/> Name="Colorful List Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 4"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 4"/>
